content.content: The financial report for November 2021 is available here.  Summary Continued positive momentum in the crypto markets led to a new all time high in risk weighted assets locked as collateral, driving higher lending and protocol income. Net protocol income was up 140% month over month, driven by a 90% ($4.7M) increase in net interest income. On a year over year basis, net interest income increased 870%.  Recurring income increased to $7.77M (+132% vs last month), driven by a 90% increase in net interest income Dai risk ratios decreased unfavorably due to a 23% increase in risk weighted assets and $5.4M Dai used on burning MKR. Leverage ratio fell by 6 bps to 0.76% and the CET1 ratio fell to 1.23%, a 22 bps decrease USDC dependency continued decreasing from 42% to 37% of assets and the peg remains safe as 37% of our assets as liquidity reserves (fiat-backed stablecoins) DAI growth reversed momentum on Arbitrum, as the market saw an 8% decrease from prior month (-18% for Dai). Dai continues to maintain the market lead on Optimism but LUSD has just entered the market and quickly taken the second most market share with $27M LUSD minted on Optimism   Selected slides  image1227×689 64.8 KB   image1225×687 79.4 KB   image1230×691 117 KB   image1229×692 167 KB   image1228×689 150 KB   image1228×689 107 KB   image1229×691 125 KB

The financial report for October 2021 is available here.  Summary Rebound in the crypto markets led to all time highs in risk weighted assets locked as collateral, driving  higher lending and protocol income. Net protocol income was down 26% month over month, driven by a 99% ($3.5M) decrease in liquidation income due to lower downward crypto market volatility. On a year over year basis, net interest income increased 490%.  Recurring income increased to $3.45M (+308% vs last month), driven by a 35% increase in net interest income DAI risk ratios decreased due to an 80% increase in risk weighted assets - leverage ratio fell by 16 bps to 0.82% and the CET1 ratio fell to 1.45%, a 97 bps decrease USDC dependency decreased from 59% to 42% of assets and the peg remains safe as 42% of our assets as liquidity reserves (fiat-backed stablecoins) New vault types launched including GUNI-DAI/USDC, StETH, and the much anticipated D3M! We also saw the first DAI drawn from the FortunaFi RWA vault DAI growth on Arbitrum is showing some signs of life but lags significantly behind USDC and USDT. DAI currently maintains the market lead on Optimism but USDC is gaining momentum with 73% month over month growth Nearly 2/3 of the Dai minted in October found it’s way to Curve, seemingly to take advantage of Liquidity Mining incentives offered in the MIM+3Crv pool   Selected slides  image1175×659 61 KB   image1176×662 71.7 KB   image1176×660 109 KB   image1176×657 113 KB   image1178×662 111 KB   image1175×661 124 KB   image1175×659 104 KB

RWA Report 2021-09 The following report is provided as an August month end snapshot. The report is split into two overarching groupings: Centrifuge RWAS and Non-Centrifuge RWAs. Within each group, individual asset pools are observed separately. A higher level RWA group summary is also provided. For each asset pool the report is organised as follows:  Pool overview Pool series summary data Performance statistics Covenant management observations   Centrifuge RWAs Highlight summary:  NewSilver is the only tinlake pool with funds drawn from Maker Vaults. Fortunafi, HarborTrade and ConsolFreight have active Maker Vaults but no debt limit utilisation. NewSilver Vault debt utilisation is steady. Maker’s debt share has grown from 47% to 56% in one month. Fortunafi existing asset pool is under close monitoring (see FF covenant section). A pre-onboarding assessment of Pipe will be done. Further risk mitigation actions from recent audit is under consideration. Harbor Trade new SCF buyer programs are close to launch. So is its Vault limit utilisation. ConsolFreight concentration limits are under review regarding single counterparties Vault utilisation thresholds.   New Silver As at Aug end: based on data reported by New Silver Pool overview: New Silver had a significant amount of new originations in the last reporting month. As Vault utilisation limit grows, NS is bringing concentration limits closer to expectations (e.g. maximum single state exposure, LTV/LTC/ARV ratios). Pool series summary:  Collateral: Commercial purpose real estate bridge loans Total loans outstanding (#): 63 Total loans outstanding ($): $13,629,450.00 New loans originated ($): $2,820,095.00 Avg loan amount outstanding ($): $216,340.48 Avg maturity (t): 12.38m Maker share of debt (%): 56.6%  Performance:  Closed/Paid loans ($): $1,168,000.00 Paid off rate (%): 7.89% In arrears ($): N/A Charge offs ($): N/A Delinquency rate (%): 0 Charge off rate (%): 0 Default rate (%): N/A Cured rate (%): N/A Recovery rate (%): N/A Payment rate (%): N/A  Covenant management: No covenant breach has been observed. We are closely monitoring the following:  Co-investors ratio: 29.06% (> 25%) Maximum single loan: 3.83% / 521K (< 10% of debt or 500K) Maximum state exposure: 27.91% (< 30% of book)  Note:  For maximum single loan the metric was setup when DC was at 5M. As DC was increased, % of debt outstanding is a  more appropriate concentration threshold. It has a positive growth trajectory and more than 100K of short term cash on hand and no other obligations than a small PPP loan. Next steps & enhancements We plan to publish these reports on a monthly basis with month end snapshots. As the dataset grows and becomes more granular we plan to:  Enrich key ratios reported by securitisation type and originator/asset manager Monitor reported variables and statistics with timeseries data Develop industry benchmarks by securitisation groupings (ABS, MBS, CLOs etc) Publish deep dives on asset pools and across the portfolio (e.g. cohort analysis, sensitivity analysis, portfolio stress tests) Host dashboards with aggregate pool performance statistics (scramble data under NDA)    Under assessment The following RWAs are currently undergoing onboarding assessment by the Core Unit, post MIP6 greenlight pool. What progress (if any) is being made on the possible buying of US Treasury Notes using the Cayman Island solution? Also - any progress on putting some legal framework around Centrifuge assets?

Planet_X:  What progress (if any) is being made on the possible buying of US Treasury Notes using the Cayman Island solution?   RWA Foundation is being created as we speak following some KYC clearance. We then have to onboard the crypto-broker and check that everything is fine. While this is for SolarX, the same will apply to such investment. Per the poll, short term investment-grade bonds were favored by the community. I was trying to find a non-US-based instrument with significant liquidity but not much success so far.     Planet_X:  Also - any progress on putting some legal framework around Centrifuge assets?   Following our call, Centrifuge and Manatt are working on that. They should come soon with a proposal.

The financial report for January 2022 is available here.  Summary Decreased lending demand driven by tightening financial conditions led to lower stability fees and recurring income. Despite lower lending demand, net protocol income was up 121% month over month, driven by a 869% ($16.3M) increase in net liquidation income. On a year over year basis, net interest income increased 312%.  Recurring income increased to $7.9M (+216% vs PY), driven by a $7.8M in net interest income vs PY Dai risk ratios increased favorably with the CET1 ratio increasing by 65 bps vs prior month to 2.11% and the liquidity ratio increasing by 15% from 44% to 59% ETH lending market share increased 2.6% from prior month, to 48.9%, as the ETH lending market contracted 6%, from 5.86M ETH locked in DeFi 1.0 protocols to 5.5M WBTC lending market share increased 0.4% vs prior month, with the overall WBTC lending market increasing by 3.5% on DeFi 1.0 protocols to 119.6K WBTC Dai outstanding grew from $9.1 to $9.35B over the past month, a 2.7% increase   Selected slides  image884×495 47.1 KB   image883×495 52 KB   image886×495 81.5 KB   image884×493 107 KB   image883×494 129 KB   image885×497 114 KB   image882×494 54.9 KB

Cover2001×1385 120 KB  Hello, another mixtape from @strat-fin-core-unit dropping. The financial report for June 2022 is available here. Please let us know your thoughts and comments on these pages. A particular thank you to @pipko who is with us for the summer and who put together an enormous amount of data for this report. As always, also big thanks to @Kayleigh for all the work putting it together.  Summary Overall Net Protocol Income was 6.7M DAI, +33% from May and -23% from June 2021. Annualized ROE on a rolling 6mo basis has begun sliding from 70-80 towards 30-40%.  After-effects from rapid deleveraging in Q2 continue to ripple through the crypto economy (LUNA → Celsius → 3AC → etc.) ETH/BTC prices continued their decline throughout June  ETH/DAI: 1,955 to 1,024 WBTC/DAI: 31,611 to 18,718 This has driven a substantial amount (impact of -1.4M DAI) of the decline in recurring revenues as vaults liquidated and users covered positions   Collateral locked also in sharp decline as major institutional users exit lending amidst broader market deleveraging  ETH locked in protocol from Ξ2.2M to Ξ1.5M WBTC locked in protocol from ₿34K to ₿63K driven by vaults protecting positions, as of 11-Jul-2022 collateral is back to ₿39K (due to Celsius loan repayment)   Total interest income decreased from 4.3M to 2.4M (-44%) month on month Overall income up on liquidations from a volatile month – from 8.6M to 9.5M (11%)  We continue to work towards solving one of the greater urgencies our protocol faces, which is correctly monetizing our balance sheet to match the cost and duration of our liabilities.  Key Strategic Discussions & Next Steps  How do we increase the slope of our balance sheet?  MIP65, Backed Finance MIP6 and other ideas to monetize our PSM How are we managing the pipeline for new RWA onboarding (Blocktower, others)? How are we managing the pipeline for new crypto collateral applications? Can we optimize parameters for existing vaults to drive usage?     Can we restructure delegate compensation to align incentives and intelligently manage the total cap? Can we ringfence GUNI DAI/USDC LP for Maker use only to capture a greater share of the fees? Discussion around developing a framework for recommending capital investment in onboarding new collateral types and maintaining existing collateral types Ongoing work on rationalizing operating expenses => 20-Jul-2022 Meeting  @Recognized-Delegates Please come to the G&R call to discuss these and other topics. Kindly familiarize yourself with the materials ahead of time. Thank you.  Selected Observations  QoQ Recurring Net Protocol Income (rNPI) declined from 21.3M to 5.0M DAI (-76%) mostly driven by change in assets and ongoing yield compression, offset by lower oracle gas costs Total interest income decreased from 4.3M to 2.4M (-44%) month on month Collateral locked also in sharp decline as major institutional users exit lending amidst broader market deleveraging MoM help on workforce expenses driven by overall phasing of drawdowns of CU budgets  Reminder: workforce expenses are reported on a cash basis so some CUs will have a timing issues with higher expenses one month and lower the next   YoY ETH lending market stabilizing and no longer in severe downturn. Long-term trend remains negative ETH lending market resumed its decline (-19.7%) on month-end Dai outstanding stabilizing around 6.5bn   Selected Slides All chart legends are now in 12pt to facilitate legibility during G&R calls, but will still burn your retinas if you’re in Dark Mode  Continued pressure on overall collateral prices and lending demand2001×1385 374 KB   rNPI drifting into negative territory as lower collateral prices have depressed lending demand2001×1385 287 KB   Collateral prices overwhelmingly drivers of negative month-on-month performance2001×1385 303 KB   Large month for liquidations as collateral prices undergo rapid decline2001×1385 181 KB   Overview of interest income model and how to think about the lending business2001×1385 382 KB   Overview of interest income decomposition into ETC, BTC, RWA, PSM and Other2001×1385 412 KB   Lending business continues to contract2001×1385 242 KB   Large increase in DAI/USDC v3 LPs as a leveraged yield farming strategy2001×1385 196 KB   Overview of Expense Rationalization Approaches2001×1385 393 KB   Overview of oracle expenses by collateral type2001×1385 293 KB   Cumulative contributed profit by collateral type2001×1385 301 KB   Illustrative financial framework for collateral profitability2001×1385 428 KB   EOA stabilizing as main use for Dai in circulation2001×1385 236 KB   ETH market share stable but overall decline in lending market2001×1385 267 KB   WBTC market share also stable with minor improvements in lending demand2001×1385 260 KB   Key strategic decisions and discussion2001×1385 333 KB   Selected Market Sentiment Readings  image932×846 60.1 KB

adcv:   How are we managing the pipeline for new RWA onboarding (Blocktower, others)?    Thanks for bringing this up, this feels really important given the current pipeline of potential issuers and the existing discourse. There is clear desire for reform and improvement of current RWA practices. There are strong opportunities in the near-term RWA pipeline (I can speak specifically to the Centrifuge pipeline, but my feeling this is true of all RWA partners/providers. The potential for long-term solutions seems to be more clear given recent governance proposals. A pipeline management conversation to balance all of these factors is exactly what is needed. My thinking is that this could occur productively along the following lines:   Identify current appetite. This should really be a discussion about desired size over the short-term timeline. Ideally informed by the Strategic Finance perspective (current portfolio, market trends, revenue needs and opportunities, etc.), but also balanced against existing resource capacity. When we talk about doing some deals, but then holding off for a reformed structure, it would be great to understand what that actually means from a size and timeline persepctive.   Immediate opportunities for improvement. Along with appetite, I think it’s critical to have an understanding of what should be prioritized, both from an asset class perspective and a process perspective, in the near-term. Less real-estate? More geographic diversity? More process documentation? Better legal framework? Obviously there is a world of desired improvements, but understanding what the DAO feels is most strongly a concern and an opportunity area is useful for issuers and service providers. Identifying where there may be low-hanging fruit we can collectively execute on would be ideal.   Long-term governance reform. RWA is a critical touch point within the recent governance proposals and discussion, so I think it’s necessary to discuss it in the context of the RWA pipeline. There was some great discussion at the end of yesterday’s DVC on this (not to mention the past two weeks) and it was centered around desires, timeline, and implementation. Taking what our current appetite is, where there are immediate opportunities, and then balancing this against a prospective timeline will help to focus activity. This is the least developed area in my mind, with the most unknown unknowns and details of governance plans still being developed, so there is no expectation of hard deadlines and details. But simply starting these discussions within the RWA context is really important for developing the long-term view.   Appreciate any feedback or other ideas from folks on this particular topic. Thanks as always to the Strategic Finance CU for some fine work.

rspa:  How can we attract more vault users, for instance? Is there anything that stands out from your analysis that could be applicable here?   I have been thinking about this too, made an informal poll with some options on how to incentivize borrowing in its current state and during this cycle (i.e. bear market). PSM and RWA initiatives are great too but growing (ar at least attempt to) core vaults in parallel would diversify DAI collateral and reduce USDC dependency. I am really excited for the L2 vaults.

Thanks, very interesting poll. In the end, it’s probably hard to incentivize vaults without depeg arb opportunities or a DSR. What other options could there be? I’m certainly not the deepest DeFi degen, so really appreciate any input here.

No matter the incentives, its clear that macros and crypto market dictates demand. However, I had proposed allowing a portion of the vault collateral to be investable in DAO approved investment options while MKR maintains a claim on the collateral in case of liquidation. This has the potential to increase SF fees but also commission fees, i.e. a % of the collateral’s investment return would be allocated to MKR for referring the funds to investment providers via a shared revenue agreement. It is important to note that this structure would not be possible under the existing vault configurations but could be considered in the creation of new vaults. It does seem like a high effort initiative though and given the tightening of budgets and resource constraints I don’t think the timing is great.

Other interest expense would include D3M but the bar has been set to 0.  MakerDAO - 2022-062001×1385 190 KB      awoldes:  Excellent report. Is there a Dune dashboard to dig into the unprofitable collaterals? I’d like to better understand if it is just bad debt in the protocol caused by vaults with this collateral + implementation expenses, or some other costs too.   @pipko put in some great work in digging into operating Oracles for various collateral types. This analysis is not surfacing bad debt, rather, it is allocating overall Oracle gas unit usage to each ilk type and subtracting it from net interest income to derive a proxy for contribution margin. Associated Dune dashboard shows the effortized gas usage per vault type, as well as highlighting the enormous work the Oracles team have put in to optimize these feeds. The takeaway is probably along the lines of ‘smaller collateral types require a higher minimum usage to justify ongoing Oracle operation’ and our next step is to derive a quantitative framework for determining the cutoff.

A few questions about methodology/presentation:   Why are the Surplus Buffer and Pause Proxy assets (labelled as Treasury) characterized as equity? Equity is the difference between assets and liabilities, and is not typically described as specific piles of segregated assets. CC: @Kurt_Barry   Why are DAI generated by the permissionless portion of the protocol listed as liabilities? Users are generating DAI on their own behalf against their own collateral. What is the reasoning for putting those DAI on Maker’s PnL as protocol liabilities?   Why are assets of users backing permissionless DAI generation listed as assets for the protocol? Those assets are not used by Maker in any way. What is the reasoning for putting those assets on Maker’s PnL as protocol assets, given that Maker describes its vaults as non-custodial?   Re: 2 and 3, could we explore whether user vault debt should be considered a loan guarantee, since Maker neither issues the debt nor is responsible for its repayment unless the user breaches collateralization requirements of the Maker protocol?   Is it possible to explore establishing contingent liabilities for losses related to Maker assuming bad user debt and then having subsequent unsuccessful liquidations? Presumably the number will be small if using historical data, but it seems like a good line item to begin including.   Is it possible to separate out DAI that has been realized vs what has simply been accrued as a receivable? If not, what information do you need to do that in the future?   Given the restatement of past liquidation income and @Davidutro stating that the numbers listed for GovComms is not in agreement with that CU’s internal numbers, is there somewhere we can follow how all these numbers are arrived at so discrepancies can be caught in real time and corrected at the source or here?   Thank you in advance for the response.

1. Why are the SB and treasury characterized as equity?     GFXlabs:  Why are the Surplus Buffer and Pause Proxy assets (labelled as Treasury) characterized as equity? Equity is the difference between assets and liabilities, and is not typically described as specific piles of segregated assets. CC: @Kurt_Barry   This schematic representation is consistent with all of our prior reports. I draw your attention to the month of August when we went into some of these representation choices. To answer the specific question, we draw a distinction between Equity and Surplus Buffer. In this view, Surplus Buffer is the equivalent of retained earnings from accumulated stability fees. The superset is Equity, which captures protocol-owned and governance-controlled assets. ENS received by governance is therefore part of the protocol’s economic perimeter (it could be liquidated for USDC for instance) and is generated externally. ENS and AAVE are not segregrated assets and are held by the Maker Protocol. The surplus buffer is captured in the accrued stability fees in vaults. It doesn’t show up as a separate account on the Asset side as it is captured in the value of the represented assets re: @Kurt_Barry question  2. Why are DAI generated by the permissionless portion of the protocol listed as liabilities?     GFXlabs:  Why are DAI generated by the permissionless portion of the protocol listed as liabilities? Users are generating DAI on their own behalf against their own collateral. What is the reasoning for putting those DAI on Maker’s PnL as protocol liabilities?   When taking a balance sheet view of MakerDAO the protocol, user-controlled vaults are assets and Dai issued is a liability. Minted Dai is redeemable, which is why it’s a liability to the protocol. We provide a non-contractual historical engagement that we will redeem DAI at peg. I draw your attention to the MakerDAO whitepaper:  Creating a Vault is not complicated, but generating Dai does create an obligation to repay the Dai, along with a Stability Fee, in order to withdraw the collateral leveraged and locked inside a Vault.  The fact that it is permissionless doesn’t change this distinction. We take the view that even a permissionless protocol is capable of being summarized through a balance sheet and income statement, even if the only people taking ‘decisions’ about its use are users external to the DAO and MKR token holders. Also, MakerDAO can take a loss on permissionless positions as user vaults can become undercollaterlized.  3. Why are assets of users backing permissionless DAI generation listed as assets for the protocol?     GFXlabs:  Why are assets of users backing permissionless DAI generation listed as assets for the protocol? Those assets are not used by Maker in any way. What is the reasoning for putting those assets on Maker’s PnL as protocol assets, given that Maker describes its vaults as non-custodial?   The contra side of the above point. As MakerDAO is a permissionless protocol, it is an interesting discussion on how to represent things accurately and in a useful way for the community. This financial report and its associated balance sheet view is one, hopefully useful, tool among many to inform token holder discussions. In brief, locked collateral is not on our balance sheet. The moment Dai is drawn, we recognize it. What is recognized is a loan against collateral, not the collateral, which remains non-custodial.    Financial Report 2022-08    Starting position1920×1329 148 KB   Providing visibility into the collateral backing DAI is critical for both MKR and DAI token holders. Not accounting for those assets would not be in the best interest of those token holders.  Can we explore considering vaults as loan guarantees? Would be interested to hear more on this if you would like to elaborate, particularly if it helps your role as a delegate.  4. Is it possible to explore establishing contingent liabilities for losses?     GFXlabs:  Is it possible to explore establishing contingent liabilities for losses related to Maker assuming bad user debt and then having subsequent unsuccessful liquidations? Presumably the number will be small if using historical data, but it seems like a good line item to begin including.   From its design, the whole of the surplus buffer is supposed to be this reserve, and the excess burned or directed to the Dai Savings Rate. As the collateral types get more complex than pure crypto collateral, it certainly makes sense to think of a design for a specific loss reserve. However, as the surplus buffer was not designed with this tiering, a view where all of it could potentially be consumed in a bad liquidation (as happened in 2020) is probably more realistic. I’d actually be a huge fan of something like a segregated senior capital reserve to shield against losses, particularly to protect Dai holders and the protocol against losses. It would have to be deployed as a separate contract, perhaps a custom vault type or a form of locked DSR (e.g. some form of fixed-rate tiered stDAI, maybe even with term specs to match Dai maturity). But this is just an idea. Maybe there is something we can build out on the DECO tech stack for this.    Simple MakerDAO — Governance from first principles    Conceptually, layers of senior or cordoned-off risk-capital can more appropriately allocate layers of risk on the Maker foundation depending on the type of project envisioned. In this framework, tokenized wholesale RWA lending could be a senior layer of stDAI in the capital stack.      Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 24 November 2022   stDAI Vault Max capacity: 10m DAI Term: 6mos Rate: 1.5%    5. Is it possible to separate out DAI that has been realized vs what has simply been accrued as a receivable?     GFXlabs:  Is it possible to separate out DAI that has been realized vs what has simply been accrued as a receivable? If not, what information do you need to do that in the future?   This is a great question–in theory until a vault is repaid, DAI has not been paid. However, from the moment a vault is opened, an obligation to repay is created, whether through a user manually closing a vault or through a liquidation. So we take the view that when a vault is updated by the protocol, the revenue is realized. In this view, it would be impractical to track accrued revenue.    Financial Report 2022-08      It’s a completely different story and WIP for RWA vaults though, completely concurr. We are hard at work building out the capabilities to understand this more deeply and will shortly prepare a proposal for our expanded mandate appropriately.  6. Hey @adcv - this is a great report - however I do have a few suggestions:     adcv:     With respect to tokenized private credit - and classification of the Drop1- Tokens. I would suggest that the criteria shouldnt be tokenized private credit for the centrifuge vaults for the following reasons:  Drop1 tokens are not held in the vault as security - they are held in the tinlakemanager contract the actual collateral in the vault is a MIP21 token as our reliance is directly on the real-world agreements to enforce the security - furthermore the liquidation status is set to manual the same as HVB There are no secondary markets in the Drop1 token  If you do want to use the tokenized classification for RWAs I think that this would only be appropriate if 2 conditions are met 1) It is a recognized token that Maker has primary reliance on for realizing on collateral; and 2) Automated liquidation is turned on so there is no reliance on real world agreements to enforce on the collateral With respect to using earning or a net income statement for these assets I think this is somewhat flawed for RWAs that dont have a RwaJar. As effectively where there is a stability fee on an RWA - when the draws are below the debt ceiling - as in Blocktower - what happens is when Drip is called on a vault is it triggers 2 key transactions - 1 booking the stability fee as income in the SB and a corresponding increase in the vault debt with respect to the stability fee charge - so effectively we have accrued the interest - and whilst we have recognized it as income - from a cash flow perspective we have deferred its payment until the vault is closed or the collateral is liquidated. This is fine for crypto native as given the interest is accrued and collateralized against a highly liquid asset - there is likely a high probability that the accrued stability fee can be converted and will be realized. For RWAs especially where liquidation is manual I think there needs to be an offsetting entry to reflect the fact that the funding of the stability fee has been accrued to the vault - to accurately reflect that not withstanding the increase in the SB - realization of that fee will not occur until vault closure/manual collateral liquidation. Likewise for MIP65 I think that we need to show the returns on an actual cash basis ie. when payments are received through the JAR - after the accumulated NAV has been sold and distributed back to the SB - as opposed to using an indicated weighted average yield to forecast income - specifically, when jar payments are made the actual income will need to factor in sell commissions. Likewise in an emergency shutdown - where income may be reduced by sell commisions.  WIth respect to the issues raised by @PaperImperium on vault debt - I think the way you have presented the asset and liabilities is appropriate and very similar to the way dealers and brokers would show margin loans in accordance with FASB keeping in mind that under FASB the collateral is usually marked to market on a daily basis.  In essence what I am suggesting overall - is if the SB balance is being used to make investment and funding decisions - we ideally should generate a cash flow statement - that adjusts for accruals and other reserves we may wish to allocate to the less liquid RWAs

dbkcan:  If you do want to use the tokenized classification for RWAs I think that this would only be appropriate if 2 conditions are met 1) It is a recognized token that Maker has primary reliance on for realizing on collateral; and 2) Automated liquidation is turned on so there is no reliance on real world agreements to enforce on the collateral   This classification makes a lot of sense, I think you are right regarding DROP-1. For now, then, we still have no tokenized private credit vaults though one would hope they will eventually be developed by the market.     dbkcan:  For RWAs especially where liquidation is manual I think there needs to be an offsetting entry to reflect the fact that the funding of the stability fee has been accrued to the vault - to accurately reflect that not withstanding the increase in the SB - realization of that fee will not occur until vault closure/manual collateral liquidation.   This part is the most complicated, and affects the implied size of the SB as you mention below. I don’t have a satisfactory idea of how to square this with on-chain transactions–in the ideal, every modification or entry would happen on-chain. So what is missing perhaps is a decentralized off-chain oracle for measuring RWA NAV values to allow for on-chain mark-to-market? This could allow for an improvement on IASB/FASB standards by offering block-on-block updates in full public view.     dbkcan:  In essence what I am suggesting overall - is if the SB balance is being used to make investment and funding decisions - we ideally should generate a cash flow statement - that adjusts for accruals and other reserves we may wish to allocate to the less liquid RWAs   I think we could do this, but it would still just be a pro-forma view, not necessarily a reflection of what would happen in reality if there was a substantial liquidation–in either the crypto vaults or illiquid RWAs–that emptied out the SB. A transaction-level live balance sheet and income statement that takes all these issues into account

I will read more carefully later but something stuck out at me. “Can we lower dependence on USDC by reducing crypto stability fees to 0%” - Maker already tried this and we observed NO change in DAI PEG when lowering SF. My analysis suggested (both in the past and still current) that the problem here is collateral.   If I have a choice of tossing $1USDC with virtually 0 fees to generate $1DAI that earns me some greater return somewhere I am going to do that vs. putting collateral into a vault and minting DAI.   The first comes with 0 fees and hence 0 risk, the second comes with SF fees and liquidation risk. Worse if the protocol does Emergency shutdown DAI basically converts to 80% USDC which sucks.  In fact this whole ES issue converting the $$ DAI value of my loan into 80% USDC is such a negative to me that I closed my DAI borrow on my ETH-USDC v2 LP, AND because if I look at security I also pulled the collateral from the vault. There are a lot of competitive protocols that are going to give you interest on your deposits while you borrow. The effects will be marginal though - we’ve tried this in the past. The calculus for those seeking leverage is whether to take leverage or not, not so much the rates (within reason). This makes sense to me. Why do you care about if you’re paying 1% or 2% when crypto is way more volatile even on a daily basis.       mhonkasalo:  Makes sense. The 2 ways to push back that come to mind here: 1. We can start lowering the rates & pull back up if there’s no positive impact. We can find this out before much is sacrificed from the buffer (& move forward with the expectation that UST revenue will come in). 2. It’s possible market has changed since 2020 & the impact would now be bigger (esp. with a marketing push). That’s just a guess though I’m not able to back it up with data.

Thank you, I have the following questions:  Net Interest Income is the income generated from minting DAI against the collateral. What is Non-Interest Income?  Where is this coming from? Is MKR outstanding the current circulating supply of MKR? What’s the formula for MKR book value per share? What is the number that PSM is exactly denoting?  Sorry for being noob, but I think these answers can be helpful. Thanks

No problem  Net interest income is generated from accumulating stability fees on yield-bearing vaults, deducted by our overall interest expense (which is the interest paid on Dai locked in the Pot, very little Dai and very little DSR atm) Non-interest income is mostly liquidation fees from vaults that are underwater and auctioned off. Maker collects something like 13% on these auctions iirc MKR outstanding is circulating supply yes, does not count the ~80k MKR in the Pause Proxy which we consider to be ‘retired’ and count it once it enters circulation again Book Value in this consideration takes the expansive view: surplus buffer + operating reserves. Operating reserves are funds sent to CU wallets for operating expenses. Theoretically they’re ‘out’ of retained earnings and the DAO has less control over them than the surplus buffer or Pause Proxy. However, they are generally actually used for operating expenses and could be recalled back to the surplus buffer. So we count them as part of the same layer of ‘Equity’ that goes into Book Value. Book Value per token is just that divided by MKR outstanding. The thinking is to show a moderately comparable heuristic to TradFi banks (that rarely trade over 1.0x) and evaluate how the market is ‘viewing’ MKR tokens whatever that is worth. The higher the multiple ~ the greater the expectation for future growth essentially (which might become unrealistic expectations if the market pumps too much). PSM counts the vaults that hold USDP, GUSD and USDC for trading against DAI. We used to charge a fee on them which would show up in Trading Income. We don’t at the moment so this is 0. We may go back to fees soon: [Signal Request] Changing USDC-PSM fees so it would show up in Non-Interest Income  Hope this is helpful, let me know if you have any other qs or comments
